conclusion: To find the work done externally by the gas from state B to state C, we need to analyze the p-V diagram and use the concept of work done in thermodynamic processes.
The process from B to C is an isobaric process (constant pressure). The pressure p remains constant at 2 x 10^5 Pa.
At state B, the volume V_B is 2 x 10^-3 m³. At state C, the volume V_C is 3 x 10^-3 m³.
The change in volume ΔV is calculated as ΔV = V_C - V_B = (3 x 10^-3) - (2 x 10^-3) = 1 x 10^-3 m³.
For an isobaric process, the work done W by the gas is given by W = p ΔV.
Substituting the values, W = (2 x 10^5 Pa) x (1 x 10^-3 m³) = 200 J.
Since the gas expands from state B to state C, the work done by the gas is positive. Therefore, the work done externally by the gas is -200 J (negative sign indicates work done by the gas).
The work done externally by the gas from state B to state C is -200 J.
